titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Medical Artifacts Collection

dsc.item:
Obj. # 1 -- Box 18
Drugs peddled by native medicine men of French Morocco.
Three phials containing: a) worm seeds for worm cures, b) iron fillings for the eyes, c) pebbles for the heart.
Donated by Miss Eleanor Fair, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New York, 1938.

Obj. # 3 -- Box 82 Mortar (stone) and pestle (stone with wooden handle).
This type of mortar was used in doctors' offices in rural areas throughout the nineteenth century. Used by William P. Moseley and his son in Buckingham County, Virginia, 1818-1896. Dr. Shelley noted: "Probably Italian and several centuries old."

Obj. # 5 -19 -- Box 17-18
Note: The following objects represent objects relating to popular medicine, collected by doctors in the rural South. One of them, Dr. Sam Morris of Alabama, was a black physician who collected many amulets and medicines from black southerners.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 5 -- Box 18
Indian Turnip.
Sliced and eaten with salt this was widely used as an aphrodisiac in the U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 6 -- Box 18
Bottle containing hog-hoof (pigs' toe nails).
Tea made from this was used to cure pneumonia, bronchitis and flu. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 7 -- Box 18
Bottle with pellets of sheeps' dung.
Tea made from this was used to make measles break out. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 8 -- Box 18
Yellow-root.
A decoction made from this was used for purgation and stomach disorders. When worn in a bag hung from the neck, it was expected to prevent all intestinal diseases. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 9 -- Box 17
Branches of witch-hazel.
Decoctions from which were used as effective abortifacients. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris (black physician), Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 10 -- Box 17
Tooth of some animal.
Suspended from the neck, it was to insure victory over enemies. Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison, Birmingham, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 11 -- Box 17
"John the Conqueror."
A piece of jointed root of an unidentified plant, to be chewed and spat out just before undertaking any severe task. It is believed to insure success in labor, lobe and battle. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris, Alabama. U.S. rural South, Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 12 -- Box 17
Yellow-root.
A decoction made from this was used for purgation and stomach disorders. When worn in a bag hung from the neck, it was expected to prevent all intestinal diseases. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 13 -- Box 17
Indian turnip.
Sliced and eaten with salt, it is widely used as an aphrodisiac. Collected by Dr. Sam Morris, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 14 -- Box 17
Irish Potatoes (2).
A black man nearing 80 used these two Irish potatoes for ten years or more as an effective preventative against rheumatism and lumbago -- one for each disease. They are dry without being brittle, and seem petrified. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 15 -- Box 17
Sheeps' dung.
Tea made from this was used to make measles break out. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 16 -- Box 17
Coin (U.S. half dollar).
Removed from the oesophageal constriction of a black woman who had accidentally swallowed it. She claimed to have used it successfully as an unfailing contraceptive measure, merely by retaining it in the mouth during coition. The coin had been conjured by an old conjuring man. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 17 -- Box 17
Mole foot.
Worn suspended from the neck to prevent venereal diseases. Collected by Dr. Sam Thelford, Boligee, Greene County, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 18 -- Box 17
French silver franc worn by black woman of 75 on a cord around waist for ten years to "prevent being conjured."
She believed that without it she would have been dead. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 19 -- Box 17
Half-dime (U.S.).
Worn about the ankle by a black woman for twelve years to attract and retain lovers. Collected by B. B. Sims, Talladega, Alabama. U. S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 20 -- Box 82
Obstetrical forceps, ca. 1870.

Obj. # 21 -- Box 18
Pill tile.
Used in the practice of medicine in the U.S. 19th century.
Donated by Dr. P. E. Tucker, Buckingham County, Virginia.

Obj. # 22 -- Box 21
Prescription scale.
Portable scale marketed under the name of Dr. C. F. Fitch. Patented September 29, 1885. Small rectangular chrome-plated metal box with a balancing slide rule attached to a spoon. Previous card stated: "Measuring weighing machine. Used in the practice of medicine in the U.S. during the period 1800-1896. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham Co., Virginia. (He had three sons in the Confederate Army: Col. W. P., Col. Edgar, and Captain Samuel P. Moseley)."
Donated by Mrs. Moseley Smith, through the courtesy of Dr. William Groce Harrison.
*Note: Stored with object #39

Obj. # 23 -- Box 21
Two single-bladed scarificators or spring lancets.
Used for blood-letting in the practice of medicine until the end of the 19th century. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia. Note: the blade is broken on one of the scarificators.
Donated by Mrs. Moseley Smith, through the courtesy of Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 24 -- Box 4
Nitze Cystoscope. Ca. 1930.
Donated by Dr. Harry Shelley.

Obj. # 26 -- Box 21
Two drug boxes U.S. 19th and early 20th century. Round.

Obj. # 27 -- Box 17
Buzzard quills and copper amulet used to make teething easy.
Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 28 -- Box 17
Copper amulet used to make teething easy.
Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 29 -- Box 17
Rabbit tobacco -- worn as a charm to prevent asthma.
A decoction made from this plant was used for the treatment of asthma. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 30 -- Box 17
Mole feet.
A charm worn to ease teething. Copper pennies were supposed to neutralize baby scents. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 31 -- Box 17
May apple root, the tea of which is used for all forms of "stomach trouble.”
Collected and donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison, Birmingham, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 32 -- Box 17
Copper wire worn on the wrist to prevent all sickness and insure physical strength.
Collected by Dr. Sam Thelford, Boligee, Greene County, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 33 -- Box 17
Buckeyes, worn on cord about the waist to prevent heart disease and to win the love of young women.
Also used to prevent hemorrhoids. Collected and donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison, Birmingham, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 34 -- Box 17
Copper penny and some unidentified bits of wood.
A charm to make teething easy. Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 35 -- Box 17
Copper pennies (two).
These coins were worn around the neck by a black woman, age 45, as a neuralgic prophylaxis. They were reputed to have cured an attack; however, in the meantime some bad teeth had been removed. Collected by H. S. Castleman, Sylacauga, Alabama. U.S. rural south. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 36 -- Box 17
Cloth-covered string.
String worn by white male, age 34, who had used it at the suggestion of an acquaintance, who claimed that such a string saturated with turpentine and tied around the waist would cure chills and fever. When the string was removed the man's rectal temperature was 106.3 which was three or four hours after the malarial paroxysm. Members of this man's family were infected with malaria, and he was not well and had been advised to take treatment, which he ignored. He admitted that he had been tortured the night before by the turpentine saturated string. Proper treatment for malaria promptly controlled the situation. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 37 -- Box 17
Amulet of small cotton bag and two beads of unidentified substance.
Said "to keep the blues away." Collected by Dr. W. H. Harper, Selma, Alabama. U.S. rural South. Early 20th century.
Donated by Dr. William Groce Harrison.

Obj. # 38 -- Box 33
Plaster cast of the hand of Dr. Barney Brooks.
Original plaster-cast of the hand of Dr. Barney Brooks, prepared by the son of Dr. Mims at the request of Dr. Allen Whipple for his "Collection of Model Hands of Famous Surgeons" in Columbia University.
Donated by Dr. Barney Brooks, December 3, 1951.

Obj. # 39 -- Box 21
Saddle-bag scales (for weighing medicines).
Wooden box with brass post and slide out drawer for scales. Early to mid-nineteenth century.
Donated by Mrs. Florence Pratt of Buckingham Court House, Virginia.
Note: Objects #122 and #39 are stored with it.

Obj. # 40 -- Box 37
Box containing a surgeon's instruments.
Two saws, three knives, two other instruments, and two needles. It contains space for three additional instruments which are missing.

Obj. # 41 -- Box 2
Saddle-bags made of leather, with leather loops inside to hold medicine bottles.
Contains five bottles, some with powders, Some with dried liquids. Used by Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia, for fifty years. U.S. Nineteenth century.
Her husband used these saddlebags as well as the instruments listed in this inventory in practice. He Was born May 31, 1794 and died April 2, 1863. He attended the University of Virginia from 1816-17, and graduated in medicine from the University of Pennsylvania. He lived and practiced in Buckingham Co., Virginia. His three sons: Col. William P.; Lieut. Col. Edgar F.; and Capt. Samuel P. fought in the Confederate army.
Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

Obj. # 42 -- Box 36
Pocket case of old surgical instruments used by Dr. John A. Tillow, Hendersonville, Tennessee about 1870.
Donated by his grandson Mr. Bransford Stone, November 10, 1942.
Donated by Bransford Stone.

Obj. # 43 -- Box 5
Scarificator.
Belonged to Dr. William P. Moseley, Buckingham County, Virginia.
Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

Obj. # 44 -- Box 4
Instrument case of Dr. William P. Moseley of Buckingham County, Virginia.
Case is of red leather and contains eight instruments; six instruments are apparently missing.
Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

Obj. # 45 -- Box 21
Wooden box containing two medicine scales and six weights.
Used by Dr. Arthur Moseley of Buckingham Co., Virginia.
Donated by Mrs. William Moseley Smith.

Obj. # 46 -- Box 51
Chinese ivory figurine from the interior of China, obtained by Miss Mary Cutter from a Chinese physician.
It was used for women patients in this manner: Modesty on part of the patient and custom forbade a personal examination; so the patient indicated on the ivory figurine the location of the pain, and the physician then prescribed. Such figurines were formerly in general use in China and still are in certain sections. Figurine is quite old (ca. 1800) and very rare.
Donated by Dr. Cobb Pilcher.

Obj. # 47 -- Box 37
Wooden case lined with velvet, containing operating set (seven instruments) belonging to Dr. W. M. Cunningham.
Dating from 1890, it was used by him in a double amputation of a patient's legs below the knee in a waiting room of a railroad station, using a caboose cushion on the floor for an operating table. The patient, Rufe Bivens, lived many years thereafter as a useful citizen.

Obj. # 48 -- Safe
Sinhalese Ola (palm-leaf manuscript).
Written on the prepared leaves of the Palmyra Palm (Borasus flabellifer) about 1745 A.D. The text is translated chiefly from the original Sanskrit writings of Charka into a mixture of Sinhalese prose and verse, dealing with various medical subjects. A part of the work is missing. Wooden covers are lacquered, and, like the binding cord and medallion (broken and in separate box) are also modern, but made by Kandyan workmen after antique models.
Donated by Dr. Casey Wood, Chicago, January 8, 1927.

Obj. # 49 -- Box 6
Box containing three lancets.
Two used by Dr. Mathieu Derivaux. The third, a cupping lancet, was used by Dr. J. O. Kirkpatrick, Nashville. All three lancets are folded between two leaves of tortoise shell.

Obj. # 50 -- Box 36
Civil War Era Surgical Instruments.
Two instruments (folded between tortoise shell leaves) from a pocket case of instruments purchased in 1859 and used through the Civil War and afterward by Dr. J. T. Harrison, Talladega, Alabama. He graduated from the University of Nashville in 1855.

Obj. # 51 -- Box 50
Portraits of Vanderbilt Chancellor Carmichael and Dean Leathers
Wooden box, 11" x 14," containing two portraits of Vanderbilt Chancellor Carmichael and Dean Leathers presented to Lt. Col. George W. Reyer, Commanding Officer of the 300th General Hospital.

Obj. # 52 -- Box 11
Truax surgical pump 1890, made by Truax Greene & Co., Chicago Ill.
Used for aspirating or irrigating cavities: "Stiff rubber tubing is inserted, then turn the crank forwards or backwards for the results desired."

Obj. # 53 -- Box 51
Wooden case, velvet lined, with ten surgical instruments (one or possibly more missing).
Instruments were given as the prize in surgery by Dr. Briggs, the professor to Robert Lee Vaught of Mason County, West Virginia, at his graduation on February 25, 1886. Dr. Vaught settled in Chattanooga as a general practitioner, specializing in surgery. Soon after he settled, he was elected Professor of Anatomy in the Chattanooga Medical College, a position he held until his death on August 28 1895 when he drowned in the Great Kanawha River while enroute to visit his mother. He was born May 24, 1863.

Obj. # 55A-E -- Safe
Medallions and medals.
A: Bronze medallion of the Johns Hopkins Hospital, to commemorate fifty years of service to humanity, science, and education 1889-1939. B: Bronze medallion of William Beaumont 1785-1853, XIII International Physiological Congress, Boston, 1929. C: Bronze medallion of Stephen Smith, founder of the American Public Health Association, commissioned to commemorate the semicentennial meeting of the association in 1922. D: Bronze medallion of Frank Billings, Dean of the Faculty, Rush Medical College, 1924. E. Bronze medal with pin and ribbon from the Tennessee State Medical Association 1930 annual convention in Nashville and commissioned to commemorate their centennial celebration.

Obj. # 56 -- Box 56
Wooden box, velvet lined, containing enema from the Truss Works, Sheffield, England.

Obj. # 57 -- Box 18
Ear speculum "before the days of light."
Donated by Dr. J. B. Hibbitts, Jr.

Obj. # 58 -- Box 5
Korean medical instruments.
Bone tube with meander- patterned metal cap, containing one large knife - "Chine," and three needle-like small "chines.” The large chine is used to open abscesses. The small chines are stuck into certain parts of the flesh for various purposes. Contained in blue cardboard box.

Obj. # 59-72 -- Box 5
Note: The drugs described on the following cards are used by Korean herb doctors. Besides regular medical doctors, there are two types of herb doctors in Korea. The older type, which still flourishes in rural areas, is learned through an apprenticeship. The modern type, which is licensed by the government, requires a student, who has attained the equivalent of a high school education, to study pharmacology in an institution. Largely, herbal medicine is taught there, but western pharmacology is taught also. It appears that the herbal medicines in this collection derive from the old-type of herb doctor. These Korean herbal medicines come in their original paper bags, and are imprinted with their names in Chinese characters. The herb medicines were introduced from China and retain their Chinese names. The small paper envelopes, imprinted with Korean characters, were merely used as containers for the want of others: they derive from the Graham Tuberculosis Sanatorium (Korean name: Kwang Ju Chai Joong). The drugs are not from the hospital.

Obj. # 137 -- Shelf 15
Framed University of Nashville Medical School diploma for Robert Dozier 1900.

Obj. # 138 -- Shelf 13
Alpha Kappa Kappa Charter to Vanderbilt, 1903, Framed.

Obj. # 139 -- Shelf 15
Abbey, Daniel.
University of Nashville Medical School diploma for Daniel Abbey, 1855. Framed.

Obj. # 142 -- Shelf 15
Whitfield, Harrison.
Medical Society of the University of Nashville diploma of membership for Harrison Whitfield, 1858. Framed.
Donated by Mr. James Bass, Vice President of American Airlines.

Obj. # 143 -- Shelf 15
Whitfield, Harrison.
University of Nashville Doctor of Medicine diploma of Harrison Whitfield, 1858. Framed.
Donated by Mr James Bass, Vice-President, American Airlines.

Obj. # 174 -- Shelf 24
Vanderbilt University Medical Department.
Framed photograph of Senior Class and Faculty, Medical Department, Vanderbilt University, 1915-1916.
Donated by Dr. C. Richard Treadway, January 31, 1978.

Obj. # 185 -- Safe
Carroll, John. Thirty-nine paintings of patients' arms, legs, and faces demonstrating pellagrous lesions. Ink and water color drawings executed by artist J. C. (John Carroll) in connection with Dr. Joseph Goldberger's work with Pellagrines in South Carolina. Each painting is accompanied with Dr Goldberger's handwritten notes on the case.
Donated by William J, Darby for Dr. Arnold E. Schaefer, June 11, 1979.

Obj. # 217 -- Box 74
Williams, Cicely.
Audio tape, magnetic one reel, of “Story of Kwashiorkor” by Dr. Cicely Williams. History of Medicine Society Lecture, December 3, 1968. 1_ I.P.S.
Donated by Dr. E. N. Todhunter, January 1980.

Obj. # 218 -- Shelf 24
Vanderbilt University Department of Dentistry.
Framed composite of the Faculty and Graduates of the Department of Dentistry of Vanderbilt University, 1901.

Obj. # 260 -- Map Case Drawer 7
Pulliam, Columbus Alonzo Monroe.
Diploma for the Doctor of Medicine degree from the University of Nashville awarded to C. A. M. Pulliam, March 1, 1860. Parchment and written in Latin.
Donated by Richard Montgomery, January 5, 1981.

Obj. # 261 -- Map Case Drawer 7
Pulliam, Columbus Alonzo Monroe
Medical Society Certificate from the University of Nashville awarded to C.A.M. Pulliam. Parchment, written in Latin, and signed by W.K. Bowling, President of the society.
Donated by Richard Montgomery January 5, 1981.

Obj. # 262 -- Map Case Drawer 7
Pulliam, Columbus Alonzo Monroe.
University of Nashville Certificate of Honor awarded to C.A.M. Pulliam, February 24, 1860. Signed by John Berrien Lindsley.
Donated by Richard Montgomery, January 5, 1981.

Obj. # 305 -- Map Case Drawer 1
Goldberger, Joseph.
Signed photograph of Dr. Joseph Goldberger, mounted and laminated.
Donated by Dr. J.H. Browe, 1985.

Obj. # 306 -- Safe
Carroll, John.
Painting by John Carroll of a woman facing left with her hands on her lap and suffering from pellagra. Ca. 1918. Laminated.
Donated by Dr. J. H. Browe, 1985.

Boothe, Archabale Alexander.
Diploma for the Doctor of Medicine degree from Vanderbilt University awarded to Archabale Alexander Boothe, March 1, 1876. Parchment and written in Latin. Rolled and contained in a card board tube. Donated by Judith Hazlewood, Librarian Luther L. Gobbel Library Lambuth College, Jackson Tennessee, 1985.
Added to inventory August 28, 1995.
Donated by Luther L. Gobbel Library, Lambuth College

Obj. # 314 -- Map Case Drawer 2

Vanderbilt University Hospital.

Obj. # 1236 Box 102
Pictorial Completion Test Illustrated by Marguerite Davis. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Copyright, 1918. Contained in a square wooden case, the test consists of a series of 11 color illustrations mounted on two plywood boards, representing a sequence of situations or events occurring during a day in the life of a boy. Each illustration contains a one inch square cutout. Each picture is to be completed by a selection of one of the 60 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

Obj. # 1237 Box 102
Pictorial Completion Test -- II By William Healey Illustrated by Marguerite Davis. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. 1964.A reproduction of the above, and contained in a square cardboard box, the test consists of a series of 11 color illustrations mounted on two plywood boards, representing a sequence of situations or events occurring during a day in the life of a boy. Each illustration contains a one-inch square cutout. Each picture is to be completed by a selection of one of the 60 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

Obj. # 1238 Box 102
Pictorial Completion Test
Illustrated by E. Manierre. Published and manufactured by Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois, ca. 1930. Contained in a wooden case, the test consists of a large illustration mounted on a plywood board. The illustration depicts ten scenes in which various activities are being depicted. There are ten one square inch cut outs adjacent to each scene Each scene is to be completed by a selection of one of the 50 accompanying squares that would best complete the illustration.
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

Obj. # 1239 Box 102
Psycho-Diagnostic Puzzles Two wood block puzzles manufactured by the Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Both are uncolored and unfinished plywood boards that have cut out shapes. One has exclusively rectangles, triangles and a square, while the other has circular pieces.
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997.

Obj. # 1240 Box 102
Bellvue Intelligence Test
Manufactured by the Psychological Corporation, New York. ca 1940s Consists of six parts contained in separate boxes. Three are wood puzzles of a human face profile, a human hand, and a mannequin. Two are picture cards, and one is a box of sixteen one cubic inch colored blocks arranged to make designs (known as the Kohs Block Design Test) There are also nine cards illustrating test patterns contained in this box of blocks.
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997

Obj. # 1241 Box 102
Kohs Block Design Test. Manufactured by the C. H. Stoelting Company Chicago, Illinois. Sixteen one cubic inch colored blocks with 18 cards illustrating test patterns. Also, a reprint of an article by S. C. Kohs entitled “The Block Design Tests undated and source not listed. Ca. 1920s
Donated by Dr. Warren Webb, January 24, 1997

Obj. # 59 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Taik Sa." A root eaten as food by the Japanese, it has a diuretic effect and is used for that purpose by the Korean medicine men.

Obj. # 60 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Yong Sa Mal.” Mercuric oxide used as a medicine for ulcers in various ways.

Obj. # 61 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Paik Chul." A root used for diarrheas, vomiting, etc. Has somewhat the effect of opium. It is a gastric tonic, increasing the appetite.

Obj. # 62 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Mercuric oxide ointment used as a medicine for ulcers.

Obj. # 63 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "O Juk San," (San means powder). Shredded wood, bark and twigs of unidentified plant. Decoction is used for acute abdominal colics.

Obj. # 64 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Chun Nam Sung." Root of a flowering plant of this name. Very poisonous. Seems to be used somewhat the way potassium iodide is used in the west. It is used, among other things, to combat glandular enlargement.

Obj. # 65 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Pujah" or "Tae Bu Ja.” Dried fruit of a tree. Has an intoxicating effect. Makes the whole body feel hot and heedless of cold weather. Temporarily it greatly increases a person's strength. It is poisonous in larger doses.

Obj. # 66 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Pal Mi Tang.” Shredded wood and other unidentified substances, decoction from which is used as an appetizer.

Obj. # 67 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Pan Ha." It is the seed of a grass. It has the effect of codeine, to some extent and is especially used to allay coughing.

Obj. # 68 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Woo Hwang Po Yong." Pills used for convulsions, green stools, fever, and vomiting in children. Instructions for usage: Grind into fine powder, dissolve in warm water or milk. Dosages to be taken three times a day. For children under 2 years: one pill; 2-3 years: two pills; and 3-5 years: three pills.

Obj. # 69 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Red pills used for indigestion and acute gastritis.

Obj. # 70 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Chun Moon Tong." Root probably used as a tonic, it is said to increase strength and agility. It is helpful in lung diseases and weaknesses. Helps to check pulmonary or gastric hemorrhages.

Obj. # 71 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Suk Ke Whang." It is a black licorice-like substance. It is supposed to cause the hair tho become white when taken, followed by eating turnips. Often used by would-be office holders to whiten their hair in order to appear older and more dignified. Improves the blood and gives a firm texture to the flesh. Is used also for amenorrhea and do improve dimmed vision. When eaten alone it makes the eye lashes black.

Obj. # 72 -- Box 5
Korean drug. Native name: "Sip Yon Tae Po Tang.” Supposed to be a great tonic for women.

Extract of Hyoscyami, 15. Alum, 16. Laudanum. Case also contains an instrument for venesection with spare blades, in red morocco leather.

Obj. # 80 -- Box 10
Intubation instruments, one complete set in black leather case lined with red velvet. These instruments were introduced in America by Dr. Joseph O'Dwyer of New York who perfected the method of intubation, and marketed the instruments. A signed a card (February 26, 1894) certifying his personal inspection, is also contained in the case.
Donated by Dr. T. Crowder Chapman, an alumnus.

Obj. # 81 -- Box 35
Douglas, Richard (“Dixie”). Death mask of Dr. Douglas who was a Professor of gynecology and Abdominal Surgery at Vanderbilt University. When the library of the School of Medicine was founded in 1906, the Nashville Academy of Medicine gave the school a Donated by the private library of Dr. Douglas, which consisted of 2,500 volumes.
Donated by Mrs. George Hale.

Obj. # 82 -- Box 2
Two Saddlebags of Dr. W. E. Pratt, Buckingham, Virginia, ca. 1895. List of medicines which can still be deciphered from the labels on the glass phials: Creosote, Borax, Morphine sulphate hypodermic, bicarbonate of soda, pulv. opium, nitroglycerin, cordia, camphor, Febralgene - neuralgic acute rheumatism and fevers generally, pepsin, quinea, paregoric gentian, nux vomica, citrate of potassium, potassium arsenate, potassium iodide, bromide potash, potassium bicarbonate, ergot (fluid extract), veratrum, aconite, cinnamon, tincture of meth., salicylic acid zinc sulphate, tincture of digitalis, chloroform, peptenzym tablets, Dad's quinine pills, chocolate coated pills for rhinitis, laxoid tablets containing cascarin, hydrastinine, and other substances.
Donated by Mrs. Florence Pratt, Buckingham, Va.

Obj. # 101 -- Box 18
Stethoscope, binaural. George P. Cammann designed the binaural stethoscope in 1851. It did not become known until 1855, when an editorial in the New York Medical Times gave it publicity. Cammann himself used it only on special occasions, for he was afraid habitual use might cause his ears to lose their natural sensitivity.
Donated by Dr Bernard M. Weinstein, Nashville, March 10, 1965.

Obj. # 351 -- Box 84
Halsted, William S.
Arterial banding device, used to occlude the aorta gradually, above the aneurysm; invented by William S. Halsted, ca. 1900. Device is contained in black wooden case with glass front, which also contains a drawing which illustrates the band's use. The drawing was also done by Dr. Halsted. Donated by Dr. W. Andrew Dale, 1985. Dr. Dale received the device and drawing in 1974 from Dr. Herman E. Pearse. following the publication of Dr. Dale's article "Beginnings of Vascular Surgery," Surgery, vol. 76 (Dec. 1974), p. 849. The article discusses Dr. Halsted's development of the banding technique.
Donated by Dr. W. Andrew Dale, 1985.

Obj. # 916 -- Box 4
Magnifier used by travelling bible salesmen in the late nineteenth century.
Squared metal rod with a graduated scale etched on the side, a stationary magnifying lens with a handle on one end, and a round metal plate with a handle which slides on the rod. The plate is inscribed with "count the dots" on the side of facing the lens. Appears to be ophthalmologic in nature.
Added to inventory March 9, 1995.

"Diabetes" and "Made in Germany" is printed on the opposite side of the insert. Contained in a black cardboard tube.
Added to inventory March 9, 1995.
